author: Antonella Artuso
title: Toronto schools close Wednesday for in-class learning
html:
Article content

Toronto elementary and secondary schools have been ordered closed, effective Wednesday, until at least April 18.

Medical Officer of Health Dr. Eileen de Villa invoked Section 22 of the Health Protection and Promotion Act in response to COVID-19 case numbers.

“Unfortunately, current circumstances require that difficult decisions must be taken locally to protect all those in our school communities, including students, teachers and staff,” a statement says. “An extension of this order may be considered based on COVID-19 epidemiological data for Toronto.

“Licensed child-care programs will not be permitted to offer care to children whose schools are required to be closed under the order, with the exception of emergency child care for those who qualify,” it says.

All classes in public elementary and secondary schools will move to online or remote learning.

“For the remainder of this week, students and staff will move to remote learning and the April Break scheduled for next week will continue as normal,” says a note from Toronto District School Board (TDSB) to parents.

Article content

“Please note that, unlike the closure in January and February, this applies to all TDSB students in all TDSB schools. School-aged children will not be permitted to attend daycares located inside TDSB schools during the closure, however, pre-school-aged children will continue to be permitted to attend.”

Unlike in January and February, schools that will be closed include those that serve only children with special needs in congregated settings.

The decision follows similar action in Peel Region, another COVID-19 hotspot struggling to keep a lid on COVID-19 cases despite being in lockdown since late November.

The move comes despite Premier Doug Ford defending the province’s position that schools remain open, telling reporters Tuesday that there have been relatively few cases among students and staff.

“Across the province, we’re looking at 98.5% — almost 99% – of the schools are currently open, 99.88% of students do not have active cases, 99.32% of students have never reported a case of COVID, 99.83% of staff do not have an active case,” Ford said. “Where we saw the problem… (was) at Christmas when the kids go back into the community, that’s where it’s happening. It’s not happening in the schools.”

Dr. David Williams, Ontario’s chief medical officer of health, described the school closures in Peel and Toronto as “temporary,” explaining that in-class learning remains generally safe, but there may be spread in some schools in these regions.
